natural problem:
Find all values of $k$ for which the system
\begin{align*}
x + ky - z &= 0, \\
kx - y - z &= 0, \\
x + y - kz &= 0
\end{align*}has a non-trivial solution.  (In other words, find all values of $k$ for which the system has a solution other than $(x,y,z) = (0,0,0).$)
natural solution: We can write the system as \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & k & -1 \\ k & -1 & -1 \\ 1 & 1 & -k \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]This system has a nontrivial system exactly when the determinant of the matrix is 0.

This determinant is \begin{align} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & k & -1 \\ k & -1 & -1 \\ 1 & 1 & -k \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} -1 & -1 \\ 1 & -k \end{vmatrix} - k \begin{vmatrix} k & -1 \\ 1 & -k \end{vmatrix} + (-1) \begin{vmatrix} k & -1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y z k :: real
assumes h0 : "x + k * y - z = 0"
and h1 : "k * x - y - z = 0"
and h2 : "x + y - k * z = 0"
and h3 : "(x, y, z) \<noteq> (0, 0, 0)"
shows  "k \<in> {-1, 0, 1}"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all values of $k$ for which the system
\begin{align*}
x + ky - z &= 0, \\
kx - y - z &= 0, \\
x + y - kz &= 0
\end{align*}has a non-trivial solution.  (In other words, find all values of $k$ for which the system has a solution other than $(x,y,z) = (0,0,0).$) The final Answer is -1,0,1
 ### Proof
 We can write the system as \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & k & -1 \\ k & -1 & -1 \\ 1 & 1 & -k \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]This system has a nontrivial system exactly when the determinant of the matrix is 0.
 This determinant is \begin{align} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & k & -1 \\ k & -1 & -1 \\ 1 & 1 & -k \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} -1 & -1 \\ 1 & -k \end{vmatrix} - k \begin{vmatrix} k & -1 \\ 1 & -k \end{vmatrix} + (-1) \begin{vmatrix} k & -1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= ((-1)(-k) - (-1)(1)) - k((k)(-k) - (-1)(1)) - ((k)(1) - (-1)(1)) \\ &= k^3 - k. \end{align}The solutions to $k^3 - k = k(k - 1)(k + 1) = 0$ are $\boxed{-1,0,1}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y z k :: real
assumes h0 : "x + k * y - z = 0"
and h1 : "k * x - y - z = 0"
and h2 : "x + y - k * z = 0"
and h3 : "(x, y, z) \<noteq> (0, 0, 0)"
shows  "k \<in> {-1, 0, 1}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the values of $k$ that satisfy the system of equations $x + ky - z = 0$, $kx - y - z = 0$ and $x + y - kz = 0$ where $(x, y, z) \neq (0, 0, 0)$. The possible values of $k$ are -1, 0, and 1.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y z k :: real
assumes h0 : "x + k*y - z = 0"
and h1 : "k*x - y - z = 0"
and h2 : "x + y - k*z = 0"
shows  "(x, y, z) \<noteq> (0, 0, 0) \<Longrightarrow> k = -1 \<or> k = 0 \<or> k = 1"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all values of $k$ for which the system
\begin{align*}
x + ky - z &= 0, \\
kx - y - z &= 0, \\
x + y - kz &= 0
\end{align*}has a non-trivial solution.  (In other words, find all values of $k$ for which the system has a solution other than $(x,y,z) = (0,0,0).$) The final Answer is -1,0,1
 ### Proof
 We can write the system as \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & k & -1 \\ k & -1 & -1 \\ 1 & 1 & -k \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]This system has a nontrivial system exactly when the determinant of the matrix is 0.
 This determinant is \begin{align} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & k & -1 \\ k & -1 & -1 \\ 1 & 1 & -k \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} -1 & -1 \\ 1 & -k \end{vmatrix} - k \begin{vmatrix} k & -1 \\ 1 & -k \end{vmatrix} + (-1) \begin{vmatrix} k & -1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= ((-1)(-k) - (-1)(1)) - k((k)(-k) - (-1)(1)) - ((k)(1) - (-1)(1)) \\ &= k^3 - k. \end{align}The solutions to $k^3 - k = k(k - 1)(k + 1) = 0$ are $\boxed{-1,0,1}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y z k :: real
assumes h0 : "x + k*y - z = 0"
and h1 : "k*x - y - z = 0"
and h2 : "x + y - k*z = 0"
shows  "(x, y, z) \<noteq> (0, 0, 0) \<Longrightarrow> k = -1 \<or> k = 0 \<or> k = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given three equations: $x + ky - z = 0$, $kx - y - z = 0$, and $x + y - kz = 0$, find the possible values of $k$ such that $(x, y, z) \neq (0, 0, 0)$. The possible values for $k$ are -1, 0, or 1.

theorem
fixes x y z k :: real
assumes h0 : "x + k*y - z = 0"

and h3 : "(x, y, z) \<noteq> (0,0,0)"
shows  "k \<in> {-1, 0, 1}"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

\begin{align*}
x + ky - z &= 0, \\
kx - y - z &= 0, \\
x + y - kz &= 0
\end{align*}has a non-trivial solution.  (In other words, find all values of $k$ for which the system has a solution other than $(x,y,z) = (0,0,0).$) The final Answer is -1,0,1

 This determinant is \begin{align} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & k & -1 \\ k & -1 & -1 \\ 1 & 1 & -k \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} -1 & -1 \\ 1 & -k \end{vmatrix} - k \begin{vmatrix} k & -1 \\ 1 & -k \end{vmatrix} + (-1) \begin{vmatrix} k & -1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\

theorem
fixes x y z k :: real
assumes h0 : "x + k*y - z = 0"
and h1 : "k*x - y - z = 0"

and h3 : "(x, y, z) \<noteq> (0,0,0)"

 *)

fixes x y z k :: real

shows  "{k. \<exists> x y z. (x, y, z) \<noteq> (0, 0, 0) \<and> (x + k*y - z = 0) \<and> (k*x - y - z = 0) \<and> (x + y - k*z = 0)} = {-1, 0, 1}"

fixes x y z k :: real
